item.title: Brazil Lifts Interest Rate to 15% as Robust Economy Fuels Inflation
item.description: Brazil’s central bank raised its key interest rate by a quarter-point, saying it will likely pause its monetary tightening campaign to gauge its impact on inflation and economic activity.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck, Andrew Rosati

media:content.media:description: The Central Bank of Brazil headquarters in Brasilia, Brazil, on Thursday, Jan. 2, 2025. Brazilian assets finished the year lagging all major peers, with the real posting its biggest slump since the pandemic shock of 2020 amid mounting skepticism over President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva's commitment to fix a ballooning budget deficit.

item.title: Taiwan Seen Holding Benchmark Rate Due to Tariff Uncertainty
item.description: Taiwan is likely to hold its benchmark interest rate for the fifth straight quarter as it considers worries about tariffs, the economy and inflation – though a surge in the local currency provides some incentive for a cut.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee, Chien-Hua Wan

media:content.media:description: Motorists ride as Taiwan Central Bank headquarters building, left, and the National Treasury Administration (NTA) building, right, stand in Taipei, Taiwan, on Monday, Jan. 22, 2018. Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen favors choosing monetary policy maker Yang Chin-long to become the next chief of Taiwan's central bank, according to a person familiar with the matter.

item.title: US Bonds Rally Stalls as Powell Endorses a Patient Fed Approach
item.description: The Treasury market stalled after Federal Reserve officials indicated they’re still on course to deliver two interest-rate reductions this year, despite the risk of resurgent inflation.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie, Ye Xie

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury building in Washington, DC. Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: Fed Officials Hold Rates Again, Still See Two Cuts by Year End
item.description: Federal Reserve officials continued to pencil in two interest-rate cuts in 2025, though new projections showed a growing divide among policymakers over the trajectory for borrowing costs as tariffs make their way through the US economy.
item.dc:creator: Amara Omeokwe

item.title: Czech Government Wins Confidence Vote Months Ahead of Election
item.description: The Czech government survived a confidence vote initiated by the opposition over a Bitcoin scandal, shouldering through the turmoil ahead of a parliamentary election scheduled for October.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Dudik

media:content.media:description: Petr Fiala, Czech Republic's prime minister, during an interview at the parliament in Prague, Czech Republic, on Friday, Dec. 6, 2024. Fiala, whose government has been among the most vocal in NATO in denouncing the Kremlin’s invasion of Ukraine, said forcing Kyiv to cede territory will only encourage Vladimir Putin’s war machine.

item.title: Brazil Braces for Thriller Rate Decision as Bank Calls Shift
item.description: On the eve of Brazil’s interest rate decision this week, XP’s Chief Economist Caio Megale agonized over data and policymaker speeches before switching his forecast to a hold from a quarter-point rise. Poring over the same details, ASA economist Leonardo Costa went the opposite way, ditching his bet on steady borrowing costs and calling for a hike instead.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck, Andrew Rosati

item.title: Why Oil Prices Are Decoupling From Geopolitical Threats
item.description: On this episode of Trumponomics, we discuss how Israel’s surprise attack on Iran and the resulting war aren’t having the expected effects on energy markets.
item.dc:creator: Sommer Saadi, Stephanie Flanders

media:content.media:description: Mandatory Credit: Photo by Ahmad Hatefi/UPI/Shutterstock (15358532t) Iranians looking as a plume of heavy smoke and fire rise from an oil refinery in Tehran, after it was hit in an overnight Israeli strike, on Sunday on June 15, 2025. An Israeli Attack on An Oil Depot in Tehran, Iran - 15 Jun 2025

item.title: Macklem Warns of Firmer Inflation, Uncertainty About Impact of Tariffs
item.description: Bank of Canada Governor Tiff Macklem reiterated that he sees inflation running hotter than expected, while saying employment appears to be holding up outside of trade-intensive sectors.
item.dc:creator: Erik Hertzberg

media:content.media:description: Tiff Macklem, governor of the Bank of Canada, during a news conference in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Wednesday, June 4, 2025. The Bank of Canada held interest rates steady for a second consecutive meeting, but officials said there may be a need to cut borrowing costs if the economy weakens and inflation remains contained as US tariffs strike.

item.title: Powell Won’t Say If He’ll Stay On as Fed Chair After Term Ends

media:content.media:description: Chairman of the US Federal Reserve Jerome Powell speaks during a news conference following an FOMC meeting in Washington, DC, on June 18.

item.title: Big Spenders Have Banks Raising Prices, Perks on Premium Cards
item.description: Sweeter benefits — and higher fees — on travel cards from Chase and Amex reflect a new US economic reality, with the richest households driving half of all consumer spending.
item.dc:creator: Paige Smith, Claire Ballentine

media:content.media:description: Shoppers on Worth Avenue in Palm Beach, Florida, US, on Saturday, April 5, 2025. President Donald Trump’s supporters in Palm Beach are trying to decide whether the tempest over his tariffs is simply another squall.

item.title: IMF Says Zimbabwe’s Economy Has Made ‘Significant Progress’
item.description: The International Monetary Fund said Zimbabwe’s economic progress represents a “regime change,” but declined to say if or when the Washington-based lender would grant it a staff-monitored program.
item.dc:creator: Godfrey Marawanyika

media:content.media:description: Shoppers browse grocery stores in the central business district of Harare, Zimbabwe, on Monday, Feb. 12, 2024. Zimbabwe may back its currency with gold in an effort to end exchange-rate instability, Finance Minister Mthuli Ncube said.

item.title: ECB’s Panetta Says Economic Outlook Faces Substantial Risks
item.description: The euro-zone’s economic prospects face “substantial” dangers that officials are struggling to assess, according to European Central Bank Governing Council member Fabio Panetta.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio, Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: Fabio Panetta

item.title: Modi Disputes Trump’s Version of India-Pakistan Ceasefire
item.description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi disputed President Donald Trump’s claims that trade deals were used to clinch a recent ceasefire with Pakistan, the latest sign of possible strain in the relationship between New Delhi and Washington.
item.dc:creator: Swati Gupta, Prateek Mazumdar, Sudhi Ranjan Sen

media:content.media:description: Narendra Modi

item.title: France’s Economy Is Falling Behind as Europe Gradually Recovers
item.description: France’s economy is falling behind the rest of Europe with weakness across the board — just as uncertainty over budget cuts looks set to return, according to the statistics office.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Tourists in the Tuileries garden in Paris.

item.title: It’s Not Cool To Be a Job Creator Right Now
item.description: What’s really going on with the labor market?
item.dc:creator: Joe Weisenthal, Tracy Alloway

media:content.media:description: Job seekers attend a Diversity Career Group job fair in Los Angeles, California, US, on Thursday, April 17, 2025. Applications for US unemployment benefits fell to the lowest level in two months, consistent with a stable labor market. Photographer: Eric Thayer/Bloomberg

item.title: UK Inheritance Tax Surge on Rich Was Mistake, Policy Author Says
item.description: One of the architects of the UK Labour government’s flagship crackdown on the wealthy said it was a “mistake” to expose non-doms to an immediate 40% inheritance tax on their overseas assets.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Joe Mayes, Benjamin Stupples

media:content.media:description: Pedestrian in London.

item.title: New Home Construction Falls to Five-Year Low
item.description: New US residential construction declined in May to the slowest pace since the onset of the pandemic as an elevated inventory of homes for sale and high mortgage rates sapped the motivation to build.
item.dc:creator: Michael Sasso

media:content.media:description: Homes in Aldie, Virginia, US, on Tuesday, Feb. 20, 2024. The US Census Bureau is scheduled to release new home sales figures on February 26.

item.title: Chile Holds Rates at 5%, Leaving Timing Open on Future Cuts
item.description: Chile’s central bank kept its interest rate unchanged and signaled it will resume cuts in coming months as long as the economic impact from global uncertainty — including the Middle East conflict — remains limited.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski, Carolina Gonzalez

item.title: Zimbabwe Asks South Africa to Back G-20 Debt Overhaul
item.description: Zimbabwe has asked South Africa to help garner support for its debt to be revamped under the Group of 20’s Common Framework, a step that could restore its access to international capital markets for the first time in more than 25 years.
item.dc:creator: Antony Sguazzin, Ray Ndlovu

media:content.media:description: Street traders in the central business district of Harare. Photographer: Cynthia R Matonhodze/Bloomberg

item.title: US Jobless Claims Stabilize Near Highest Levels This Year
item.description: Applications for US unemployment benefits ticked down last week, stabilizing near the highest levels in eight months.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard

media:content.media:description: A jobseeker fills out forms during a career fair in Wilmington, North Carolina.

item.title: Euro Zone Is Still Held Back by Rising Mortgage Rates, ECB Finds
item.description: Household consumption in the euro area will remain restrained for some time as past interest-rate hikes continue to feed through to mortgages, according to research by the European Central Bank.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

item.title: South Africa, US to Resume Trade Talks as Tariff Deadline Looms
item.description: South Africa will resume trade talks with the Trump administration on the sidelines of the US-Africa Business Summit next week, with less than a month to go before Washington’s reciprocal tariffs are set to come into effect.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: South Africa's president Cyril Ramaphosa and US President Donald Trump during a meeting in the Oval Office in Washington, DC, on May 21.

item.title: UK Home Prices See Biggest Drop Since 2021 as Tax Hike Kicks In
item.description: UK home prices fell in April by most since 2021, government data show, as a tax increase drove some buyers out of the market.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

item.title: Fed Ponders If Tariff Hit Is Less, or Just Later, Than Expected
item.description: I’m Chris Anstey, an economics editor in Boston and today we’re looking at the upcoming Fed policy meeting. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

item.title: Trump Taps Tariff Toolkit to Hit Consumer Goods
item.description: With President Donald Trump’s universal tariffs possibly headed for a Supreme Court showdown, his administration is pressing ahead with another strategy that could hit an equally broad swath of imports.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

item.title: Riksbank Cuts Key Rate and Signals Potential for More Easing
item.description: Sweden’s central bank lowered borrowing costs by a quarter point, resuming attempts to jump-start growth in the biggest Nordic economy, and raised the prospect of one more cut this year.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Duxbury

media:content.media:description: The Slussen transport hub in Stockholm.

item.title: Norway Will Keep Waiting Before First Rate Cut
item.description: Norway’s central bank is poised to stick with one of the most hawkish policy stances among advanced economies, holding off on any start to post-pandemic easing until later this year.
item.dc:creator: Ott Ummelas

item.title: Bank Indonesia Official Summoned as Witness in Graft Case
item.description: A Bank Indonesia deputy governor will testify this week as a witness in a graft case related to the use of corporate social responsibility funds.
item.dc:creator: Grace Sihombing, Chandra Asmara

media:content.media:description: Filianingsih Hendarta Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

item.title: Philippine Central Bank Chief Calls Peso Intervention Futile
item.description: The Philippines will tolerate the slide in its currency to a two-month low, with the central bank governor flagging that interventions won’t be effective in the face of global risk aversion.
item.dc:creator: Andreo Calonzo, Prima Wirayani

media:content.media:description: Eli Remolona Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

item.title: PBOC Head Imagines New World Currency Order After Dollar Era
item.description: People’s Bank of China Governor Pan Gongsheng laid out in the clearest terms yet his vision for the future of a new global currency order after decades of dollar dominance, predicting a more competitive system will take root in the years to come.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Wenjin Lv, Yujing Liu, Zheng Li

media:content.media:description: Pan Gongsheng
